cells.data:
What is the deal with `gets.chomp`? Is there a reason behind using chomp in the command? It’s throwing me off, like there is something else to the command other than getting input

cdownard [1:44 AM] ah, so chomp. when you press enter on your keyboard in a command prompt, it’s a line return or new line operation. `/n`

cdownard[1:44 AM]if you were writing C code, you’d have to handle this yourself, but ruby has a helper

cdownard[1:44 AM]if you use gets, you get the `/n`, if you use chomp, you don’t

cdownard[1:45 AM]i.e. if you type
```>input
```
as the response to a prompt for input in a ruby program, then gets is going to get a string that under the hood looks like this: `”input/n”` (edited)

cdownard[1:46 AM]i might have that slash backwards… it might be \n but i’m blanking on that at the moment

tiffany.js [1:46 AM] Ohhhhhh okay

tiffany.js[1:46 AM]So you’d add chomp to remove the new line and kind of just make one line/sentence

cdownard [1:46 AM] it’s totally left leaning. so it’s `\n`. i thought that looked funny while typing it

cdownard[1:47 AM]right

tiffany.js [1:47 AM] For instance I am writing this 'print "How old are you? "
age = gets.chomp
print "How tall are you? "
height = gets.chomp
print "How much do you weigh? "
weight = gets.chomp
puts "So, you're #{age} old, #{height} tall and #{weight} heavy.”`

cdownard [1:47 AM] in C, the null terminator is `\0` (zero). and you still have to trim that in plenty of languages especially if changing string encoding

cdownard[1:47 AM]yeeup. that’s perfect :simple_smile:

tiffany.js [1:47 AM] Ohhh okay

cdownard [1:47 AM] although come on, let’s change heavy

tiffany.js [1:48 AM] Zed Shaw

tiffany.js[1:48 AM]LOL

tiffany.js[1:48 AM]So is there a way to glean input that doesn’t automatically add a new line to the input that is entered?

cdownard [1:49 AM] 
```puts "So, you're #{age} old, #{height} tall and #{weight} #{(weight >= 0 && weight <= 250) ? ‘light’ : ‘heavy’}.” 
```
(edited)

cdownard[1:49 AM]no this is something in how a computer works, or at least how they’re written.

tiffany.js [1:49 AM] Okay.

cdownard [1:50 AM] it’s a really old concept and the first thing you have to learn in a language like C.

cdownard[1:51 AM]but like i said, you have to chop null terminators depending on what you’re doing. so it’s a good thing to learn early. for instance, when decoding certain encryption, if the null terminator isn’t automatically replaced for you as part of the function call you’ll need to do that or you won’t be able to decrypt.

cdownard[1:51 AM]i have personally hit that one, or rather helped devs fix it i guess
